sections.title: Introduction (Wide Shot)
sections.content: Hello everyone, welcome back to our Python tutorial series! In this video, we’re going to dive into Python variables and data types. Understanding these concepts is essential for any beginner, so let’s get started!

sections.title: What are Variables? (Wide Shot)
sections.content: First, let's talk about what variables are. A variable in Python is a way to store information to be referenced and manipulated in a program. It's a name given to a memory location.

sections.title: Declaring Variables (Close Shot + Screen Recording)
sections.content: For example, let's declare a variable.
sections.code:
x = 5
y = "Hello, World!"
# Here, `x` is a variable that holds the integer value 5, and `y` is a variable that holds the string 'Hello, World!'.

sections.title: Introduction to Data Types (Wide Shot)
sections.content: Now, let's talk about data types. Data types specify the type of data that a variable can hold. Python has several built-in data types, such as integers, floats, strings, and booleans. Let's look at some examples.

sections.title: Integers and Floats (Close Shot + Screen Recording)
sections.content: First, we have integers and floats. Integers are whole numbers, and floats are decimal numbers.
sections.code:
a = 10  # Integer
b = 20.5  # Float
print(a)
print(b)

sections.title: Strings (Close Shot + Screen Recording)
sections.content: Next, we have strings, which are sequences of characters.

sections.title: Lists (Close Shot + Screen Recording)
sections.content: Lists are ordered collections of items.

sections.title: Tuples (Close Shot + Screen Recording)
sections.content: Tuples are similar to lists, but they are immutable, meaning they cannot be changed after creation.

sections.title: Basic Operations with Data Types (Close Shot + Screen Recording)
sections.content: Let's now see how to perform basic operations with these data types. We'll start with arithmetic operations on integers and floats.
sections.code:
num1 = 10
num2 = 5
print(num1 + num2)  # Addition
print(num1 - num2)  # Subtraction
print(num1 * num2)  # Multiplication
print(num1 / num2)  # Division

sections.title: String Operations (Close Shot + Screen Recording)
sections.content: String operations include concatenation and slicing.
sections.code:
greeting = "Hello"
name = "Alice"
message = greeting + ", " + name + "!"
print(message)
print(message[0:5])  # Slicing

sections.title: List Operations (Close Shot + Screen Recording)
sections.content: You can also manipulate lists easily.
sections.code:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
fruits.append("orange")  # Adding an item
print(fruits)
fruits.remove("banana")  # Removing an item
print(fruits)

sections.title: Dictionary Operations (Close Shot + Screen Recording)
sections.content: Dictionaries allow you to access and modify values using keys.
sections.code:
student = {"name": "Alice", "age": 25}
student["age"] = 26  # Modifying a value
print(student)
print(student["name"])  # Accessing a value

sections.title: Conclusion (Wide Shot)
sections.content:
And that's a wrap on Python variables and data types! We’ve covered integers, floats, strings, booleans, lists, tuples, and dictionaries, along with some basic operations you can perform with them.
Thanks for watching! Don’t forget to like, comment, and subscribe for more Python tutorials. If you have any questions or topics you’d like us to cover, leave them in the comments below. Happy coding!
